ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also prerecorded mini-seminars on research topics relating to the course material.
Live virtual lecture with "mini seminar" recordings to supplement
virtual seminars
Office hours and study groups.
I attended almost every lecture, but I was able to view recorded lectures on days that I was forced to miss lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course covers the main components of conventional water treatment. Prof Kim goes into detail about a lot of these processes, but also focuses on teaching engineering skills (like mass balances) that apply to many of the different components.
how to work a Brita filter

I learned a lot about basically how to build a water treatment plant for different source waters and for different "purposes" ie which filters work best for x contaminant, etc. I really liked this course a lot and think I will use the information I learned here later in my career.

I learned about the steps of modern water treatment and how engineers model them: disinfection, coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, mass transfer, and more. Most models built off of mass balances and transport phenomena.
I developed the ability to think critically about different water purification systems and when to apply the proper design equations to optimize purification processes.
the complete ins and outs of water treatment plants
An understanding of water treatment industrial process, as well as the math and engineering fundamentals needed to analyze these systems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
One strength is that the course builds on fundamental skills that come back throughout the course. Prof Kim really focuses on mass balances in the first few chapters, and this comes back throughout the course. 
The course also does a good job of connecting the relevant math to the bigger picture understanding of the physical process going on.
Honestly I think this course was structured really well, I see no serious flaw/weakness to improve upon.  Prof. Kim is great and I think overall the class went really well.

Strengths: Prof. Kim knows his stuff and is willing to break down the material and repeat it several times if necessary. Its also at a decently basic level, so its a good introduction to the subject.
Weaknesses: Prof. Kim said he got rid of lots of wastewater-related topics, since Peccias class covers them, but I wouldve liked to see more here. Not everyones going to take it as an elective, and its an important subject in env eng.

A big strength of this course is the instructor's pace. The instructor ensures to repeat himself if he notices that some students look lost, or if he knows the subject material is rigorous and upper level. I would point out that the structure of recitation in relation to homework due dates is a weakness. It'd be preferable for me to have recitation earlier than the day before the homework's due date.
Prof Kim is incredible

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Kim used slides that he annotated in Zoom. For the most part, this worked really well. Sometimes the writing wasn't perfectly neat, but it was usually legible. The one drawback was that the annotations weren't saved (although a recording of the lecture was saved)
I felt that out of my courses, this one was the least flexible in its course material and it showed through a more rigid exam schedule (timed, in-class) and in general, more material than usual.

I think this was the class that I was most likely to attend even though attendance was not factored into the grade.  I'm not sure if it's because I'm afraid of Prof. Kim because he is very impressive/important in the department or if I just like him so much (possibly both).  I really enjoyed his lectures, even though I am not good at participating (in general but especially on zoom).
All practices succeeded I would say

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Prof Kim is an incredible teacher and this class is really interesting.

I would definitely recommend this course to an engineering student as an elective. The material is very interesting and relevant. The workload for the course is very manageable and the exams are designed so that you don't have to memorize formulas and you only need to understand key concepts. Professor Kim is an absolute joy in class and teaches with the intent to give his students useful skills.

I would absolutely recommend this course.  Professor Kim is a great teacher and I was really happy to have the chance to take a class with him.  I feel I learned a lot and as an environmental engineer/someone interested in water, I think material from this course will continue to be relevant to me for many years to come.
Yes! Its a good class and you learn how to apply what you are learning.

Yeah, if you think you want to work in the field! Its very focused on the nuts and bolts of drinking water treatment, so dont expect a class on how water quality changes in the environment. But its insane to think about how the water that comes out of your tap gets there, and its a pretty easy class.

Definitely an interesting class that is a bit more tangible than others in the chemical engineering curriculum. Dr. Kim is a great professor who is very patient and understanding. Would recommend this course to any student interested in the subject material whether they're studying engineering or not.
